DOC.HEAD: Retailer Takes Toy Off Market
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. says it is immediately pulling off the market a toy that simulates a rocket booster blowing up. Four Boise children had complained the toy represented ``sick humor'' after the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger. Sears spokesman Gordon Jones said Wednesday in an interview from Chicago that the Building Blaster toy is ``removed from sale. We will not fill orders.'' Jones said the toy was pulled ``out of concern that we may have offended some customers.'' He said the company had as many as 100 complaints. The sons of Christa and Gary Sanders _ Jared, 13, Seth, 9, Spencer, 5, and Cody, 3 _ spotted the toy in the Sears holiday Wishbook catalog and wrote Sears and President Bush to complain. ``We don't want children learning to blow up space shuttles!'' they wrote. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration got the Sanders' letter to Bush and submitted a complaint of its own to Sears. Jared praised the withdrawal of the product, but said, ``That's something they should have thought of earlier.'' The toy, available only through the toy catalog, was advertised in the Wishbook as ``simulating a countdown gone awry. Construct the rocket pad and prepare missile for launch. Ticking timer detonation device destroys the entire structure.'' John Bohach, a vice president of the manufacturer, Kenner Products Inc., said from Cincinnati that the company had no intention of equating the toy with the Challenger. He said the company found that ``kids like to build things and like to knock them down.'' Jones said two other toys in the Building Blaster series, a communications tower and a bridge, also are withdrawn.
